Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2016 12:02AM Selizabeth12 wrote: I have to politely disagree with the statement above "Mammo and us will show up abnormalities along with skilled experts you will be in great hands" My mom went to "highly skilled" experts every single year for her mammograms. She never missed a year. She had a clear mammogram at the women's center in my city and a professional breast examination done at another time by our primary care doctor just months before she found her stage 3 cancer herself. Even after it was confirmed that she had cancer, they could not locate the cancer via mammogram. It only showed up on an MRI (her pathology report noted at LEAST 10 different foci.. None of which ever showed on the mammogram) It's been over a year since her diagnosis and I listen to and question all of her doctors often. You wouldn't believe the mistakes I have noticed that they have made- one including administering her chemo at double the rate that it was supposed to be given at. Shortly after I noticed and alerted the nurse she started having horrible back spasms due to the lack of attention to detail that unfortunately happens sometimes. Women think that they are "safe" after clear mammograms but the truth is that mammograms do not detect everything. If society would stop giving women a false impression that the mammogram is the holy grail detection tool, a lot of women would find their cancers a lot sooner. My point is, you can never be too safe and should never trust a doctor just because they are a doctor. If you have a gut feeling, always seek a second opinion. But it's really great that you seem to have a really educated and caring doctor who is being proactive about the situation! I think you can feel reassured that if there is a problem, your doctor is being proactive about finding it. But like others have said- most of the time it will turn out just fine and I hope that is the case for you as well :) the painful lump you are referring to deep down very well might just be a rib you are feeling as well. I know my moms surgeon said that sometimes it is hard to tell the difference between a rib and a lump that is deep down.
